Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental and Computational Studies on CO2 Photoreduction to Fuels by Nanostructured Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Institution: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee / Arizona State University
Title: Collaborative Research: Experimental and Computational Studies on CO2 Photoreduction to Fuels by Nanostructured Catalysts

Intellectual Merit

Carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere is a potentially sustainable source of carbon for the production of renewable fuels. The photocatalytic conversion of CO2 and water to hydrocarbons is a particularly attractive route, as it uses solar energy as the source of reducing electrons to drive this conversion process. However, the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 is an extremely challenging task due to the stable thermodynamic properties of CO2. The low yield of CO2 conversion calls for more efficient photocatalysts, but the development of efficient photocatalysts requires understanding of CO2?catalyst interactions and electron transfer pathways deduced from computational studies at the molecular level. The overall objective of the proposed research is to use solar radiation to photocatalytically reduce CO2 to fuels (CO, methane, methanol, and other hydrocarbons) at high conversion efficiency through manipulation of catalyst composition and nanostructure. Toward this end, the proposed research has three objectives. The first objective is to fabricate nanostructured photocatalysts, specifically brookite-containing mixed-phase TiO2 nanoparticles with controlled phase contents such as lattice-doped iodine and surface Cu clusters, to achieve visible light responsiveness and facilitate charge separation. The second objective is to develop a fundamental understanding of the catalyst properties and charge separation mechanism at the mixed-phase (e.g., anatase-brookite) nanocrystalline interfaces through closely coupled experiments and computational chemistry (density functional theory) modeling. The third objective is to optimize catalyst composition and nanostructure (e.g., TiO2 phase composition, crystal size, surface structures, dopant concentration, etc.) to synergistically improve CO2 photoreduction efficiency. In this regard, the proposed research will integrate experimental and computational approaches to evaluate brookite-based catalyst activity toward CO2 photoreduction, and will advance fundamental understanding in the multidisciplinary areas of material science, surface chemistry, photocatalysis, and nanotechnology.

Broader Impacts

Processes for photoreduction of CO2 and water to hydrocarbon fuels tackle the simultaneous challenges of greenhouse gas management and renewable fuels production. The educational and outreach activities will be in the context of the proposed research. Topics related to CO2 reduction and solar fuels will be incorporated into solar engineering, chemical reactor design, and air quality engineering courses at Arizona State University (ASU) and the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM). Outreach activities at ASU sponsored though the Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering (IAFSE) will provide hands-on experiences in solar fuels to students from underrepresented groups as well as local teachers. An animated educational module on CO2 conversion by sunlight will also be created to engage students and the general public. This module will be posted on the websites of the principal investigators as well as on the ASU IAFSE outreach website. Complimentary outreach activities at UWM will be coordinated through the Urban Ecology Center (UEC) in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, who has partnerships with forty-four inner-city elementary and high schools and provides ?outdoor classrooms? in science education for urban youth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we aimed to use sunlight as the sole energy input to convert carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas, and water to fuels and useful chemicals like carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4) and hydrogen (H2), by developing photocatalysts that have novel nanostructures and are composed of inexpensive and earthabundant materials. Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 is a big scientific challenge because CO2 is a very stable chemical, photoinduced electron-hole pairs recombine very fast within the photocatalyst, and the utilization of visible light spectrum is limited. To provide a viable solution for these challenges, we have fabricated novel nanostructured photocatalysts with unique advantages: (1) bicrystalline anatase-brookite mixed-phase TiO2 nanoparticles with controlled phase contents to promote photo-induced charge transfer between anatase and brookite; (2) oxygen deficient TiO2 nanocrystals that can enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2 compared with perfect TiO2; (3) surface loading of copper species and lattice doping of iodine in TiO2 to improve charge transfer and the responses to visible light; (4) silver-incorporated bicrystalline anatase-brookite TiO2 microspheres with enhanced electron-hole separation. Experiments on CO2 photocatalytic reduction with water were conducted to evaluate the performance of the synthesized photocatalysts. CO and CH4 were identified as the major reaction products for all experiments. The new materials developed in this projects have demonstrated much higher activities than conventional photocatalyts. For example, oxygen deficient brookite showed eight times higher activity than perfect brookite; copper and iodine co-modified TiO2 showed ten times higher activity than pure TiO2. In addition, we have developed fundamental mechanistic understanding of the CO2 photoreduction reaction by a coupling photocatalytic experiments with computational density functional theory (DFT) modeling to probe CO2 activation on different crystals and surfaces, and by conducting in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) to investigate surface reaction intermediates and reaction pathways. It was found bicarbonates and anion CO2- species are active intermediates that possibly lead to the formation of CO. Subsequent surface reactions involving multiple electrons result in the formation of CH4. The surface properties and catalytic activities are closed related.

Findings from this project have advanced the development of cost-effective photocatalyst materials for sustainable fuels production by recycling greenhouse gases. This project has resulted the publication of one book chapter, seven peer-reviewed journal articles, thirteen conference presentations and posters, one PhD thesis and one master thesis, and has trained one postdoc, four graduate students and two undergraduate students. Education outreach activities were conducted in collaboration with the Urban Ecology Center (UEC) in Milwaukee and trained six educators in UEC on solar energy and nanotechnology. This project also trained three high school science and math teachers through an NSF Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program. The UEC educators and the high school teachers are now incorporating the research they have learned into their class teaching. The PI of this project also gave several presentations at the UEC’s annual lecture series on solar energy and greenhouse gas control technologies to an audience of local community members. Through the above educational and outreach activities, this project has made broad impacts at the university, K-12, and the general public levels by increasing the awareness of global climate change and renewable fuels and by encouraging broadened participation in the activities of greenhouse gas control.
